CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Maria Smith (later MA) was born in London; she was an only child.

SHORTPROSE.P: As a member of the English professional classes and an adherent of the established Anglican church, she was presumably white and relatively privileged, but little is known of her life. Her mother's family were Dissenters.
MA's mother, Maria Smith, bore this name both before and after her marriage.
Richard Smith, her father, was a solicitor.
MA's maternal uncles, James and Horace Smith, who were influential in her early life, wrote Rejected Addresses, 1812.
She grew up in the area of Russell Square.
Interested in science, she was frustrated by how few of its mysteries she could comprehend.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Maria Smith married John Channing Abdy, the rector of a Southwark church (variously given as St John's or St George the Martyr's).

SHORTPROSE.P: MA's husband died in 1845.

P.CHILDREN: Their only child, Albert Channing, was born by 3 July 1829. He grew up to become a clergyman.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: MA died at 7 Upper Marine Terrace in Margate.

SHORTPROSE.P: The cause was pronounced decay of nature by the doctor present at her death. She was buried in St Peter's Churchyard, on the Isle of Thanet in Kent.

FILEDESC.SOURCEDESC: Based on original research by members of the Orlando Project.

P.GENERICRANGE: MA, whose work spans the Romantic and Victorian periods, was a poet who wrote wittily on religious and secular topics, and was an early champion of the governess. With Felicia Hemans, she was the one of the two most prolific British contributors to annuals in the USA.

P.PFIRSTLITERARYACTIVITY: MA was writing rhymes at the age of nine, demonstrating a talent for literature at an early age.

P.PPERIODICALPUBLICATION: MA's husband, the Reverend John Channing, encouraged her to submit poems to the New Monthly Magazine. These appeared under her initials. She also contributed to the Metropolitan (edited by Thomas Campbell),
P.PANTHOLOGIZATION: and her work appeared in a number of annuals: The Keepsake (1835 and onwards), the Literary Souvenir, the Forget-Me-Not, The Juvenile Forget-Me-Not, Ackermann's Juvenile Forget-Me-Not. the Book of Beauty, Friendship's Offering, and A New Year's Gift.

SHORTPROSE.P: My Very Particular Friend appeared in the Comic Offering of 1834.

P.RRESPONSES: This popular poem is one of MA's humorous pieces, which according to critic Paula R. Feldman were her most imaginative and successful

PINFLUENCESHER.PINFLUENCESHER: compositions. Although some of her devotional verse has been viewed as monotonous, her comic pieces were witty and perceptive, and were possibly influenced by the writing style of her uncles, James and Horace Smith.

PAUTHORSHIP.RBESTKNOWNWORK: MA, as Mrs. Abdy, printed for private circulation the first volume in her eight-volume series Poetry.

PMODEOFPUBLICATION.PEDITIONS: Between 1838 and 1862 seven more volumes were privately printed, under the same title.

P.PARCHIVALLOCATION: The British Library has two editions which include personal notes to friends.

P.RRESPONSES: In the late nineteenth century MA's poems were praised for their religious spirit and grace of style.
More recently the Feminist Companion found them witty and sharply observant with an intriguing strain of distinct but very gentle feminism.

SHORTPROSE.P:
In The Poetess she writes,
Methought the votive crowd's assiduous duty
Surpassed the homage paid alone to Beauty:
I learned the causeâ€”her high and gifted lays
Had won the public ear, the public praise.

A later poem, The Dream of the Poetess, addresses similar themes. A Match of Affection and The Chaperon's Complaint take up the marriage market issue in an ironic tone. A Governess Wanted is a satirical poem in which a sister describes to her brother the heroic qualifications expected for the job:
She must point out each author's chief beauties,
She must manage dull natures with skill,
Her pleasures must lie in her duties,
She must never be nervous or ill!

CHRONPROSE.RRECOGNITIONS: MA produced a prize-winning poem, An Appeal on Behalf of Governesses.

SHORTPROSE.P:
The prize was given for the best poem on the plight of governesses. Although apparently her longest poem, her entry does not appear in any of the eight volumes of her series Poetry. Other poems in the series attest to MA's desire to further the cause of the oppressed. The Writer of the People (1858) pronounces:
A glorious privilege to thee belongs;
Tis thine, with wise and vigilant inspection
To guard the People's rights, to scan their wrongs,
And urge their claims to justice and protection.

P.PMANUSCRIPTHISTORY: MA's books and papers were inherited by her son, Albert Channing.

RRESPONSES.PANTHOLOGIZATION: After a century of neglect, several of her pieces have recently been included in late-twentieth-century anthologies of Romantic poets.

SCHOLARNOTE.P: Her married name is sometimes spelled Neville.

SHORTPROSE.P: The birthdate of Frances Manners (later FNBA) is unknown; it was probably before 1540.
FNBA belonged to the English upper class.
Her mother was Eleanor (Paston) Manners, Countess of Rutland.

FNBA's father, Thomas Manners, third Earl of Rutland, was one of the peers who tried Anne Boleyn for treason.
Horace Walpole was wrong in calling FNBA's aunt, Joan, Lady Bergavenny, an author.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Frances Manners married Henry Nevill, Baron Abergavenny, by this date.

SHORTPROSE.P: Her husband was one of those who tried Mary Queen of Scots.

P.CHILDREN: FNBA had one daughter, Mary (Nevill) Fane, to whom she entrusted her collection of prayers.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Frances Neville, Baroness Abergavenny, died, having entrusted her collection of prayers to her daughter on her deathbed.

FILEDESC.SOURCEDESC: Based on original research by members of the Orlando Project.

SHORTPROSE.P: FNBA seems to have both collected and composed devotional writings during the sixteenth century: a very early date.

HEADING.TITLE: The Praiers made by the right Honourable Ladie Frances Aburgavennie

TEXTSCOPE.PLACEHOLDER: FNBA, The Praiers made by the right Honourable Ladie Frances Aburgavennie, 1582

PATTITUDES.PAUTHORSHIP: FNBA highly valued her collection of prayers, mostly in prose. They were apparently composed by herself,

PCIRCULATION.PMOTIVES: since she entrusted them to her only daughter on her deathbed as a Jewell of health for the soule.

SHORTPROSE.P: The collection draws on the Psalms. It comprises prayers, mainly in prose, some of them lengthy, for every occasion of life, including childbirth. According to Susan M. Felch (writing about the devotional collection made at about the same date by Elizabeth, Lady Tyrwhit) the popular private prayer-book genre is a significant index of the way that ordinary believers created a living blend out of disparate and even warring religious traditions. Lady Abergavenny says women's labour pains are the rod of [God's] correction, but that it is Christ's mercy which produces women's delivery. Her collection ends with an acrostic on her own name, and one in verse on her daughter's.

P.PANTHOLOGIZATION: Her prayers became publicly known: Thomas Bentley printed them in his Monument of Matrones in 1582 under the title The Praiers made by the right Honourable Ladie Frances Aburgavennie, and committed at the houre of hir death, to the right Worshipfull Ladie Marie Fane (hir onlie daughter) as a Jewell of health for the soule, and a perfect path to Paradise, verie profitable to be used of everie faithfull Christian man and woman.
P.RRESPONSES: Horace Walpole meant to honour her in his Catalogue of Royal and Noble Authors of England in 1758, though he confused her with her aunt Joan, Lady Bergavenny.

SCHOLARNOTE.P: VA renamed herself when she became serious about being a poet. From about 1930, she used the androgynous name of Valentine Ackland, partly as a pen-name and partly as a disguise appropriate to the lesbian identity that she had adopted by this time.
VA was called Molly by family and friends until her mid-twenties.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Mary Kathleen McCrory Ackland (later VA) was born at 54 Brook Street in London.

P.BIRTHPOSITION: She was the younger of her parents' two daughters.

SHORTPROSE.P: She was born into a wealthy, upper-middle-class English family. Her childhood in London was fashionable, with riding in Rotten Row and shopping at Selfridge's department store opposite the family house in Brook Street. She wore such clothes as a white velvet coat with a beaver-edged collar and a tricorne velvet and beaver hat. When she was seventeen, she enjoyed a London season. In this world, according to Ackland, it was fashionable to commit extravagances and follies, and she committed them, despite the fact that she was extremely shy. Unfortunately she began to overcome her shyness by drinking, and eventually developed a serious drinking problem.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Mary Ackland (later VA) was given a coming-out dance in London's Savoy Ballroom.

SHORTPROSE.P: As a child, VA was a fervent Anglo-Catholic, following her mother's example. Later in life she became a Roman Catholic, struggled with her Catholicism, and eventually became a Quaker.

VA engaged in many lesbian relationships in her life. She states: I was naturally more inclined to love women than men. She also had brief sexual relationships with men during her youth, as well as an unconsummated marriage of short duration.

During VA's childhood, she lived alternately in the fashionable heart of London and at the family's holiday house at Winterton in Norfolk. The Norfolk community of fishermen and their families seemed like home to her, and she considered Norfolk her spiritual home all her life.

VA's mother, Ruth Ackland, was a tireless High Anglican, given to organising the neighbourhood and the village in charitable causes. But alongside this formidable communty involvement, she remained uninvolved in her younger daughter's life, and indeed largely ignored her.

VA's father, Robert Craig Ackland, was a successful West End dentist. Relations between him and Mary (later Valentine) broke down in her teenage years when she had a relationship with one of the young women at her school in Paris. He brought her home and sent her to domestic science college in Eastbourne as a punishment. Shortly thereafter he died suddenly of cancer, having never forgiven her.

Until the age of sixteen, VA was educated at Queen's College in Harley Street, London, which she likened to a convent and described as a most expensive public school for young ladies. In addition to regular lessons, she took extra lessons in riding, violin, and swimming.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: On a visit to Italy with her parents, Mary Ackland (later VA) fell in love for the first time in her life, with a young woman.
Mary Ackland (later VA) was sent to Paris to live with three middle-aged sisters, the Mademoiselles de Rigny, for further education.
In Paris Mary Ackland (later VA) fell in love again, this time with Lana, a fellow student there.

SHORTPROSE.P: Her father was horrified and angry at their love, calling it filthy and unnatural. Mary was told that she would go blind and mad as a result of her unnaturalness.

CHRONPROSE.CONTESTEDBEHAVIOUR: The father of Mary Ackland (later VA), disgusted by her relationship with a fellow pupil in Paris, sent her to a Domestic Training College at Eastbourne to learn Domestic Economy.

SHORTPROSE.P: She felt completely out of place and only stayed a few weeks. No one from her social class attended the school, and the other students had no interest in the literature, painting, and music which she had been studying up to that point.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Mary Ackland (later VA) carried on a lesbian relationship with Bo Foster, a wealthy young speaker for the Conservative Party, with whom she fell in love at eighteen.

SHORTPROSE.P: VA calls Foster X in her autobiography. They remained lovers during Ackland's marriage, and their relationship lasted until she fell in love with Sylvia Townsend Warner.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Mary Ackland (later VA) married Richard Turpin at the Westminster Registrar's Office, London.

SHORTPROSE.P: The marriage was never consummated, and was annulled a few years later. Turpin was a dealer in stamps who later became a novelist.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Mary Ackland (later VA) was received (with her new husband, Richard Turpin) into the Catholic Church.

SHORTPROSE.P: Thanks to the encouragement of Bo Foster (who was her lover at the time), VA had been taking Catholic instruction. She was troubled about how to reconcile the Catholic sacrament of Confession with her lesbian relationship, but Foster's and her own reasoning (that God would not blame their love) prevailed. Gradually, however, VA lapsed from her faith.

Having been received into the Catholic Church, Ackland and Turpin were re-married at Westminster Cathedral eight days after their civil marriage at the Westminster Registrar's Office. She wore a white dress and a nun-like coif for her head to cover the fact that she had had her hair Eton-cropped the morning of the wedding. The short haircut made her look extremely boyish and shocked the assembled guests, much to her delight.

From the beginning, the marriage was not a happy one. Ackland was in a lesbian relationship (with Foster) at the time, and Turpin had enjoyed homosexual relationships. After an early dinner on their wedding day, the newlyweds drove to a nursing home, where Turpin had a minor operation the next morning, and stayed in hospital for a week. Later they were unable to consummate the marriage, since Ackland found sexual intercourse too painful.

Because of the pain she experienced in attempting penetrative intercourse with her husband, VA then had an operation to have her hymen stretched, which she found humiliating. After the operation, she decided that she did not wish to return to Turpin.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Mary Turpin (later VA) discovered during her brief marriage that she was pregnant as a result of an even briefer extra-marital affair; the pregnancy produced much turmoil, but ended in miscarriage.

SHORTPROSE.P: Early the next year, still pregnant, she suggested to her husband that he should agree to a divorce. Initially he resisted this and offered instead to accept her illegitimate child as his own if she would return to him. She refused this offer, and eventually persuaded him to adopt her plans. Pursuing a divorce for non-consummation, she underwent a medical examination so cursory that the doctor failed to realise that she was pregnant. This careless examination, coupled with the testimony of the doctor who performed the operation on her hymen and with her own false testimony, persuaded the Catholic Church to grant an annulment of her marriage on the grounds that she was virgo intacta.
VA was deeply disappointed when this pregnancy ended in miscarriage.

After she left her husband, VA spent a good deal of time at Chaldon in Dorset. There, she was able to write and join a supportive community of artistic friends, including Theodore Powys and his wife Violet, Llewelyn Powys and his wife Alyse Gregory, Philippa Powys, Betty Muntz, and Stephen Tomlin, among many others. She numbered among her friends the artists Augustus John and Eric Gill.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: VA and Sylvia Townsend Warner committed themselves to each other in a lesbian marriage.

SHORTPROSE.P: Their relationship had begun on 11 October 1930, soon after they first met, at Chaldon in Dorset. Warner remained true to Ackland, despite the latter's infidelities, until Ackland's death.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: VA and Sylvia Townsend Warner lived in Miss Green's cottage at Chaldon Herring.

SHORTPROSE.P: In 1933 they moved to Frankfort Manor in Norfolk, partly because VA's mother lived close by in Winterton. However, they became disenchanted with the amount of work and money needed to keep up the large property. VA's alcoholism was also a problem, as was her mother's proximity. In 1935 they moved back to Chaldon, to live in a primitive stone cottage known as 24 West Chaldon.

In 1937, Ackland and Warner moved to Lower Frome Vauchurch on the river Frome, near Maiden Newton, where they lived for the rest of their lives. Early in the Second World War, from April to November 1940, they moved to Winterton in Norfolk to look after Ackland's mother, who was alone.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: VA began an intimate relationship with Elizabeth Wade White, a young American friend of both Ackland and Sylvia Townsend Warner.

SHORTPROSE.P: The three women had done political work together during the Spanish Civil War. VA's relationship with Sylvia Townsend Warner became increasingly strained as a result of this affair with White, which continued for more than ten years.

CHRONPROSE.LIVESWITH: VA lived with her lover, Elizabeth Wade White, in the same house that Ackland had shared with Sylvia Townsend Warner for many years at Lower Frome Vauchurch.

SHORTPROSE.P: Sylvia Townsend Warner, who had originally bought the house, wished not to pressure VA, but to allow her the freedom to choose whom she preferred as a partner. She moved out to live in lodgings nearby, rejecting VA's suggestion that they should all live as a threesome. At this point Ackland, realising that Warner's love and support were critical to her, ended her relationship with White, who went home to her partner in America. Although the experiment only lasted a month, the resulting disruption to the relationship between Warner and Ackland lasted much longer.
Despite these and other difficulties, VA and Warner celebrated the thirty-seventh anniversary of their marriage on 12 January 1968, shortly before VA became terminally ill.

Although there was no tradition of political involvement in either of their family backgrounds, VA and Warner became politically active during the 1930s because of events in Europe. In particular, they became convinced of the need for a Popular Front in Britain. Ackland, who was shy, was far less outspoken and argumentative politically than Warner, but she too was regarded in Wessex as a top Communist Party activist.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: VA and Warner joined the Communist Party, believing, like many of their contemporaries, that Communism offered the best or only defence against encroaching Fascism.

SHORTPROSE.P: They were involved as Communist Party members in a daily struggle for social change until they left for the United States in 1939. They began compiling a scrapbook of the political struggles in Europe and Britain, and sold the Daily Worker at an enormous peace rally at Dorchester. They struggled to convince the agricultural workers of Dorset to emerge from deference to the interfering gentry and instead take command of their own social lives. Among Popular Front projects, VA began a book-lending scheme designed to initiate readers gradually into Socialism.

With Warner, Ackland was a member of publisher Victor Gollancz's Left Book Club. Her connection with the Left Review brought her into contact with intellectuals such as Edgell Rickword and his wife Johnnie, Julius Lipton and his wife Queenie, Jack Lindsay, Tom Wintringham, and Montagu Slater.

VA and Warner were involved in the Spanish Civil War from its outset. They travelled to Barcelona as first-aid volunteers in late September 1936 in response to an article written by Nancy Cunard in the Daily Worker, and were attached for three weeks to the Primera Unidad Sanitaria Britanica and the Primera Ambulancia Inglesa en Espana. After they returned to England, they worked on countless Aid-Spain committees, and Ackland, in particular, longed to return to Spain.Spanish Civil War A year later, VA and Warner made a second visit to Spain, attending the Second Congress of the International Association of Writers for the Defence of Culture, held in Madrid.

Stephen Spender's later autobiography incorporates a vitriolic personal attack on both women and their work in Spain. Such unthinking heterosexism and homophobia is (says biographer Wendy Mulford) an index of attitudes prevailing among privileged left-wing intellectuals of the day in Britain, even highly-educated people convinced of their own progressiveness. at the time. Spanish Republicans, on the other hand, had no problem welcoming and accepting the two women as intellectual comrades. Ackland's and Warner's peace work continued until May 1939, when they sailed to the United States.

Sylvia Townsend Warner and Ackland travelled together to New York in May 1939 to attend the Third Congress of American Writers. Their postwar holidays included trips to Italy in February 1949, and to County Clare in Ireland (where they almost bought a house) and the Auvergne in France in 1950. That winter, November to March 1951, they rented Great Eye Folly at Salthouse on the North Norfolk coast. In 1966 and 1967, they took their last two sea-air-and-salt-water holidays to Scotland. Despite Ackland's breast cancer (diagnosed early in 1968) and her mastectomy, they went on a trip to see Clough and Amabel Williams-Ellis in Portmeirion, North Wales in September 1968.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: VA experienced what she called a crisis, which enabled her, over time, to conquer her addiction to alcohol.

SHORTPROSE.P: She had been unsuccessfully seeking medical help and struggling to free herself of her nineteen-year-old alcohol addiction.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: VA opened an antique shop in Lower Frome Vauchurch, where she lived with Sylvia Townsend Warner.

SHORTPROSE.P: VA established her shop in a room known in the village as the Long Room. She built up a good reputation for customer service and a successful mail-order business, mostly with the United States. By May 1966 she felt too ill to carry on the business except as an agency to supply particular items to customers. Warner closed the shop after Ackland died.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: During these years, VA was attempting to find her way back to some kind of religious faith.

SHORTPROSE.P: The issues of religion and politics caused great unhappiness between Ackland and her lifelong partner, Sylvia Townsend Warner, almost destroying their relationship. Ackland became increasingly right-wing, and their political views diverged sharply.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: VA was received back into the Catholic Church on the anniversary of her first reception into it.

SHORTPROSE.P: A few years later, however, she left again, disenchanted with the liberalising changes in the Church effected by the Second Vatican Council (convened on 11 October 1962).

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: VA was accepted as a member of the Society of Friends; she remained a Quaker during the remaining two months of her life.

SHORTPROSE.P: VA was reacting to her own personal doubts: her inability to deal with what she felt to be the Anglicanisation of the Catholic Mass, and her disbelief in the concept of one true Church. She felt that the Quaker philosophy matched her current way of thinking. Warner, relieved that Ackland was no longer a Catholic, went with her to Quaker meetings; they found it comforting to attend together.

Late in VA's life, during the period of her reconversion to Catholicism, her political views diverged significantly from Warner's. Ackland became increasingly right-wing and anti-Communist, and, during the 1960s, complained about the Labour government.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: VA voted Liberal (against Harold Wilson's Labour government) in the general election, a departure from socialism which pained Warner considerably.

SHORTPROSE.P: In the 1950's VA suffered pains in her breast, which were mistakenly diagnosed as cancer. Later she suffered a thyroid condition, and, in March 1960, was found to have temporal arthritis. This was treated with cortisone, a special diet, and rest. In February 1963 she was diagnosed with high blood pressure, and, two months later, in April, was admitted to hospital to receive anticoagulation treatments and tests for tuberculosis of the pericardium.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: VA suffered a car crash, which undermined her confidence to the point that often she felt unable to drive.
VA was diagnosed as having cancer in her left breast.

SHORTPROSE.P: An operation was carried out by Sir Hedley Atkins, President of the Royal College of Surgeons, on April 10th to remove the cancerous lump, at the Nuffield Ward of Guy's Hospital in London. A mastectomy followed in December. The cancer, however, spread to Ackland's lungs. She was nursed at home until she died, less than a year after the mastectomy.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: VA died of cancer of the lungs (metastasised breast cancer) at her home at Frome Vauchurch in Dorset.

SHORTPROSE.P:
VA and Sylvia Townsend Warner are buried together in the churchyard of the East Chaldon Church. The stone reads Non omnis moriar, an epitaph that VA chose.
The Latin phrase is taken from Horace (Odes III 30, 6). It forms the opening words of a claim to immortality for the poet, which translates into English: I shall not altogether die; a great part of me will escape Libitina (death).

FILEDESC.SOURCEDESC: Based on original research by members of the Orlando Project.

SHORTPROSE.P: VA published very little in her lifetime, and has gone largely unrecognised since. Her lifelong partner, Sylvia Townsend Warner, was very supportive of Ackland and helped her to get her writing into print. This writing (which dates from four decades of the mid twentieth century) took the form of poetry, as well as political critique, an autobiography, and letters. VA contributed articles regularly to magazines such as Country Standard, Left Review, and The Countryman, none of which paid very well. At present she is better known for her association with Warner than for anything she wrote herself.

From the mid-1930s until the mid-1940s, Ackland published many of her early poems in the New Republic, New Masses, and The New Yorker. At that time Edmund Wilson, among others, appreciated her poetry. She always considered herself a poet, and wanted recognition only for her poems, not for herself. After World War Two, her poetry appeared comparatively dated, and she was saddened when her later poems went unrecognised. Sylvia Townsend Warner published several collections of Ackland's poetry posthumously, which together represent more than ever appeared during Warner's lifetime.
Much of the information above comes from a brief, unattributed biographical note at the end of Ackland's book of poetry, The Nature of the Moment, edited and published posthumously in 1973 by Sylvia Townsend Warner.

TEXTSCOPE.PLACEHOLDER: Warner, Sylvia Townsend, and VA, Whether a Dove or a Seagull, 1933

RBESTKNOWNWORK.PDEDICATION: VA, with Sylvia Townsend Warner, published Whether a Dove or Seagull, a collection of love poems.

P.PAUTHORSHIP: In the American edition, published by Viking Press in November 1933, the two authors' love poems are printed with no attributions, so that readers could not ascertain who wrote each individual poem.
P.PEDITIONS: However, in the English edition, published by Chatto and Windus in March 1934, a key appears at the back of the volume identifying which woman wrote each poem.

P.PEARNINGS: VA's account at her publisher Viking Press was always overdrawn because she ordered innumerable copies of the book for her family and friends.

TTECHNIQUES.TVOICENARRATION: The poems are arranged so that the love poems respond to each other.

P.PAUTHORSHIP: Warner and Ackland point out in a Note to the Reader, which is a kind of manifesto, that the text is not a collaboration, but rather a joint collection of their poetry. They explain that the book is a political experiment, designed in a spirit of protest. Withholding the authorial signature was intended to prevent readers from critiquing the poems according to the pre-determined merit of the author. Claire Harman in VA's ODNB invokes the similarly unattributed collaboration of Wordsworth and Coleridge in Lyrical Ballads, 1798.

P.RRESPONSES: Nonetheless, American reviewers chose to focus almost exclusively on comparisons between the poets, and to avoid the same response in England Warner asked that the English publishers include a key. This, however, undermined the explanation in the manifesto, leaving English reviewers puzzled. The few reviews that discussed the quality of the poems, rather than the novel presentation of them, were predominantly positive; they seem to have felt unable to comment on the physically explicit, erotic diction.

Robert Frost, too, the volume's dedicatee, wrote to Louis Untermeyer: Don't you find the contemplation of their kind of collusion emasculating? I am chilled to the marrow. Frost also pleaded with Untermeyer play down any connection between himself and the book. In spite of his disapproval, Frost did find some poems beauties, and he wanted to tell their authors this. It took him, however, more than a month to thank them for their dedication.

CHRONPROSE.PPERIODICALPUBLICATION: VA's first article, Country Dealings, appeared in the Left Review, arguing that there was a scarcity of good, state-run hospitals, and advocating the benefits of Communism.

P.PPERIODICALPUBLICATION: She published two subsequent articles in May and September, describing the poverty-stricken, precarious status of farm-labourers and the exploitative activities of landowners.
VA also wrote regularly for the Daily Worker and New Masses.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: VA published Country Conditions, a book that portrayed a depressed agricultural village based on East Chaldon, where she lived.

P.PMATERIALCONDITIONS: She wrote the book (almost short enough to be a tract) in Rat's Barn, a quiet cottage on the downs that belonged to the family of T. F. Powys.

SHORTPROSE.P: The book extended ideas covered in her articles for the Left Review. The text's downtrodden family was based on tenants living at East Chaldon with Ackland and Sylvia Townsend Warner. Ackland added appendices of farm wages across the country and comparisons of hours and wages of workers in the USSR with those in Germany and Italy to support her argument.

P.RRESPONSES: Reviews were positive, but mostly confined to the Party parish. A reviewer in the Times Literary Supplement dismissed the book as distorted propaganda, but most were enthusiastic, particularly about the effectiveness of the restrained method VA used to argue her case.

RRESPONSES.PEARNINGS: The book sold well, and her first royalty cheque was for Â£4 0s 4d.

TEXTSCOPE.PLACEHOLDER: VA, For Sylvia: An Honest Account, 1985

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: VA finished writing her painful confessional memoir, For Sylvia: An Honest Account, and gave it to her lifelong partner, Sylvia Townsend Warner.

SHORTPROSE.P: VA experienced a spiritual crisis of total despair on 8 October 1947, and decided, at that moment, to stop drinking. This event was the beginning point for her autobiography. Warner, privy to Ackland's diaries and ideas, abhorred the spiritual journey which she felt to be entirely robbing Ackland of self-esteem, and tried to frame her strong criticism of Ackland's soul-purging in a delicate enough manner not to give offence. Ackland, however, remained firm in her convictions and continued in her diary to detail what she saw as her soul's corruption.

The work portrayed her new spiritual awareness that she had in the past been selfish, destructive, and insensitive to others, and her feelings of worthlessness and wastefulness. It also detailed her remorse and conflicted feelings over being in love with both Sylvia Townsend Warner and Elizabeth Wade White.

CHRONPROSE.PMODEOFPUBLICATION: For Sylvia: An Honest Account, VA's confessional memoir, was finally published by Chatto and Windus, after the deaths of both Ackland and Sylvia Townsend Warner, with a foreword by Bea Howe.
Twenty-Eight Poems, a small collection of VA's poems, was prepared and privately printed by Sylvia Townsend Warner.
The year after VA's death, a booklet of her poems, titled Later Poems, was privately printed by Sylvia Townsend Warner as a keepsake for friends .

CHRONPROSE.PMODEOFPUBLICATION: A substantial collection of VA's poems, edited by Sylvia Townsend Warner, was published posthumously as The Nature of the Moment.

TITLE.REG: I'll Stand By You: Selected Letters of Sylvia Townsend Warner and Valentine Ackland

TEXTSCOPE.PLACEHOLDER: Warner, Sylvia Townsend, and VA, I'll Stand By You: Selected Letters of STW and VA, 1998

SHORTPROSE.P: Not until 1998 were any of VA's letters published. In that year about a third of the huge correspondence exchanged between her and her longtime lover was published as I'll Stand By You: Selected Letters of Sylvia Townsend Warner and Valentine Ackland. The collection was edited by Susanna Pinney, who started working for Warner shortly after Ackland's death, typing the entire collection of letters between the two women. Warner sent the typescript to the Berg Collection in the New York Public Library, and later gave the originals, and her linking narrative, to Pinney. She took steps to prevent publication until certain people mentioned in the letters were dead. The collection was too large for a volume; only about a third has been printed.

The letters are an intimate portrayal of the thirty-nine-year love affair between Warner and Ackland, from their first meeting until Ackland's death. Written when the two women were together and apart, the correspondence is a detailed account of their lesbian relationship. Included is their initial falling in love, their wedding night, the disruptive affair that Ackland had with another woman, Ackland's intense involvement with Catholicism in the latter part of her life (which distressed Warner almost beyond bearing), and the courageous way they both managed to cope with the devastation of Ackland's terminal illness.

Though VA's poems were well received when they first began to appear, she was always a poet out of step with her time: more in tune, as Claire Harman remarks, with writers of the seventeenth to the early nineteenth century who are in themselves minority tastes, from Thomas Traherne to George Crabbe. Her failure to win recognition for her work was one of several elements in her personal unhappiness. Despite Warner's energetic work to build her reputation, she remains little known today outside a nucleus of lesbian admirers. By the year 2008, she had no entry in Contemporary Authors or the Dictionary of Literary Biography. She is, however, included in the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

Also in 2008, a selection of VA's poetry appeared entitled Journey From Winter. Charles Bainbridge, welcoming this volume as long-overdue, argued that Ackland's intensely musical and ambitious love poetry constitutes her best work, especially the late poems, in which a remarkable sense of shared experience battle[s] in the face of physical decay.
